Tech.summary:
## Executive Summary
Jest, a new marketplace for messaging games, has emerged with $7 million in seed funding, challenging the traditional app store model. Meanwhile, Burger King is using AI to evaluate employee interactions with customers and assist with meal preparation. Anthropic, a company focused on AI safety, has loosened its core safety promise due to competition. Additionally, research has shown that password managers' claims of being "zero knowledge" are not always true. 

## Market & Business Implications
* Jest's launch coincides with the rise of Rich Communication Services (RCS), which supported over a billion messages daily in the US by May 2025, according to Google (Article 1).
* Burger King is using an AI-powered chatbot called "Patty" to evaluate employee interactions with customers and assist with meal preparation, as part of its BK Assistant platform (Article 2).
* Anthropic has adopted a nonbinding safety framework, citing shortcomings in its previous Responsible Scaling Policy that could hinder its ability to compete in the AI market (Article 3).
* Research has identified ways that someone with control over a password manager's server can access user data, despite claims of being "zero knowledge" (Article 4).

## Beginner-Friendly Summary
There's a new company called Jest that wants to change how we play games on our phones. Burger King is using a computer program to help its employees be nicer to customers. A company called Anthropic is changing its rules for keeping its artificial intelligence safe. Also, some password managers aren't as secure as they claim to be.

articles.title: Jest, a marketplace for messaging games, is challenging the app store status quo
articles.text:
For years now, when we think of mobile gaming, we think of app stores. Developers invest countless hours, months, or even years creating games just to surrender a significant portion‚Äîup to 30%‚Äîof their earnings to major players like Apple and Google. However, a newcomer has entered the scene, aiming to revolutionize this model.

Meet Jest, a marketplace for messaging games that recently emerged from stealth with $7 million in seed funding. Jest believes that the future of gaming won‚Äôt come from an app store, but rather from right within your messaging app.

Jest‚Äôs launch coincides with the rise of Rich Communication Services (RCS), an enhanced version of SMS that enables more engaging experiences through rich media, interactive features, and embedded payments. With RCS making significant advancements, the landscape is shifting dramatically. In 2024, Apple joined the RCS movement with iOS 18, and by May 2025, RCS was supporting over a billion messages daily in the U.S., according to Google.

‚ÄúMobile game developers have largely been locked into app store distribution as the primary way to reach players,‚Äù Deyan Vitanov, CEO and co-founder, said in an interview with TechCrunch. ‚ÄúRCS games live in the messaging inbox, the stickiest surface on mobile, where people are already spending huge amounts of time talking to friends and family. We‚Äôre building on an interaction pattern people already use every day.‚Äù

Image Credits:Jest

Jest offers users the ability to send games directly in their chat threads, without having to visit an app store. (Games launch in the web browser and require Wi-Fi to play.) This convenience is particularly impactful as consumers are downloading fewer games. In 2025, mobile games were downloaded 39.4 billion times, reflecting an 8.6% year-over-year decline following a 6.6% drop from 2023 to 2024, according to Appfigures‚Äô annual report.

Jest‚Äôs strategy is proving effective. By the end of January, just four months into its beta phase, the platform

articles.title: Burger King will use AI to check if employees say ‚Äòplease‚Äô and ‚Äòthank you‚Äô
articles.text:
is a news writer who covers the streaming wars, consumer tech, crypto, social media, and much more. Previously, she was a writer and editor at MUO.

Posts from this author will be added to your daily email digest and your homepage feed.

Burger King is launching an AI chatbot that will live in the headsets used by employees. The voice-enabled chatbot, called ‚ÄúPatty,‚Äù is part of an overarching BK Assistant platform that will not only assist employees with meal preparation but also evaluate their interactions with customers for ‚Äúfriendliness.‚Äù

Thibault Roux, Burger King‚Äôs chief digital officer, tells The Verge that the company compiled information from franchisees and guests on how to measure friendliness, resulting in the fast food chain training its AI system to recognize certain words and phrases, such as ‚Äúwelcome to Burger King,‚Äù ‚Äúplease,‚Äù and ‚Äúthank you.‚Äù Managers can then ask the AI assistant how their location is performing on friendliness. ‚ÄúThis is all meant to be a coaching tool,‚Äù Roux says, adding that the company is ‚Äúiterating‚Äù on capturing the tone of conversations as well.

The OpenAI-powered Patty serves as the ‚Äúvoice‚Äù of the BK Assistant platform, which combines data across drive-thru conversations, kitchen equipment, inventory, and other areas of the Burger King business. Employees can ask Patty questions, such as how many strips of bacon to put on a Maple Bourbon BBQ Whopper, or for instructions on how to clean the shake machine.

Because it‚Äôs integrated with the new cloud point-of-sale system, the AI assistant will also alert managers if a machine is down for maintenance or when an item is out of stock. ‚ÄúWithin 15 minutes, the entire ecosystem will remove it from stock ‚Äî whether you‚Äôre walking into a restaurant to order from the kiosk, whether you‚Äôre going to the drive-thru, the digital menu board will be updated,‚Äù Roux says.

Burger King may be building a chatbot into employees‚Äô headsets, but it doesn‚Äôt seem like the brand is ready to widely launch

articles.title: Anthropic ditches its core safety promise
articles.text:
Anthropic, a company founded by OpenAI exiles worried about the dangers of AI, is loosening its core safety principle in response to competition.

Instead of self-imposed guardrails constraining its development of AI models, Anthropic is adopting a nonbinding safety framework that it says can and will change.

In a blog post Tuesday outlining its new policy, Anthropic said shortcomings in its two-year-old Responsible Scaling Policy could hinder its ability to compete in a rapidly growing AI market.

The announcement is surprising, because Anthropic has described itself as the AI company with a ‚Äúsoul.‚Äù It also comes the same week that Anthropic is fighting a significant battle with the Pentagon over AI red lines.

The policy change is separate and unrelated to Anthropic‚Äôs discussions with the Pentagon, according to a source familiar with the matter. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth gave Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei an ultimatum on Tuesday to roll back the company‚Äôs AI safeguards or risk losing a $200 million Pentagon contract. The Pentagon threatened to put Anthropic on what is effectively a government blacklist.

But the company said in its blog post that its previous safety policy was designed to build industry consensus around mitigating AI risks ‚Äì guardrails that the industry blew through. Anthropic also noted its safety policy was out of step with Washington‚Äôs current anti-regulatory political climate.

Anthropic‚Äôs previous policy stipulated that it should pause training more powerful models if their capabilities outstripped the company‚Äôs ability to control them and ensure their safety ‚Äî a measure that‚Äôs been removed in the new policy. Anthropic argued that responsible AI developers pausing growth while less careful actors plowed ahead could ‚Äúresult in a world that is less safe.‚Äù

As part of the new policy, Anthropic said it will separate its own safety plans from its recommendations for the AI industry.

Anthropic wrote that it had hoped its original safety princip

articles.title: Password managers' promise that they can't see your vaults isn't always true
articles.text:
Over the past 15 years, password managers have grown from a niche security tool used by the technology savvy into an indispensable security tool for the masses, with an estimated 94 million US adults‚Äîor roughly 36 percent of them‚Äîhaving adopted them. They store not only passwords for pension, financial, and email accounts, but also cryptocurrency credentials, payment card numbers, and other sensitive data.

All eight of the top password managers have adopted the term ‚Äúzero knowledge‚Äù to describe the complex encryption system they use to protect the data vaults that users store on their servers. The definitions vary slightly from vendor to vendor, but they generally boil down to one bold assurance: that there is no way for malicious insiders or hackers who manage to compromise the cloud infrastructure to steal vaults or data stored in them. These promises make sense, given previous breaches of LastPass and the reasonable expectation that state-level hackers have both the motive and capability to obtain password vaults belonging to high-value targets.

A bold assurance debunked

Typical of these claims are those made by Bitwarden, Dashlane, and LastPass, which together are used by roughly 60 million people. Bitwarden, for example, says that ‚Äúnot even the team at Bitwarden can read your data (even if we wanted to).‚Äù Dashlane, meanwhile, says that without a user‚Äôs master password, ‚Äúmalicious actors can‚Äôt steal the information, even if Dashlane‚Äôs servers are compromised.‚Äù LastPass says that no one can access the ‚Äúdata stored in your LastPass vault, except you (not even LastPass).‚Äù

New research shows that these claims aren‚Äôt true in all cases, particularly when account recovery is in place or password managers are set to share vaults or organize users into groups. The researchers reverse-engineered or closely analyzed Bitwarden, Dashlane, and LastPass and identified ways that someone with control over the server‚Äîeither administrative or the result of a compromise‚Äîcan, in

articles.title: Best Tested Ski Clothes (2026): Shells, Jackets, Wool Socks
articles.text:
Honorable Mentions

During the winter, a whole WIRED crew tests ski clothes almost constantly. Here are a few other items that we like.

Courtesy of REI

Hestra Fall Line 3-Finger Gloves for $190: I've long admired Hestra gloves from across the lift line, impressed by the Swedish company's elegant stitchwork and thoughtful design touches. This was the year I finally got to try a pair for myself, and the Fall Line are exactly what they look like. There are six sizes available so you can get the perfect fit in this glove. The cowhide is buttery smooth and has already broken in a bit with five days' use. The wrist strap means you never have to fret about dropping your glove from the lift when checking your phone, and they're very warm without making me sweat. If you do sweat, the lining is removable so you can wash it without damaging the leather. ‚ÄîMartin Cizmar

Courtesy of Crab Grab

Crab Grab Snuggler Mitts for $89: These mini sleeping bags for your fingers are packed full of Primaloft insulation and benefitting from a sherpa fleece lining, they are toasty warm, and with a 15K membrane, impressively waterproof too. All-season mittens with durable construction for under $100? Yes Please!

Courtesy of Mons Royale

Mons Royale Yotei Merino Classic Long Sleeve for $98: As I type this, I‚Äôm nowhere near a mountain, but I‚Äôm still wearing the Mons Royale Yotei long sleeve top. It is ridiculously comfortable, made from 190-gsm-weight, 100 percent merino wool, and has a mercifully relaxed cut, so I remain warm, but don‚Äôt feel like a sausage. On the mountain however, the merino wool works its magic, wicking away sweat‚Äîespecially on a hike up to some fresh powder‚Äîand keeping me comfortable. Paired with a shell and the Patagonia R1 Thermal Hoodie, I‚Äôm warm enough during a bitter arctic blast.

Seniq Powder Puff Down Jacket and Bib Photograph: Kristin Canning

Seniq Powder Puff Down Jacket for $498 and Bib for $398: Seniq is another all-women‚Äôs outdoor brand that launched in 2024

AI.summary:
## Executive Summary
Burger King is launching an AI chatbot called "Patty" to evaluate employee interactions with customers and assist with meal preparation. Salesforce reported a solid quarter with $10.7 billion in revenue, but investors are concerned about the impact of AI on the company's business model. Riley Walz, a software engineer, is joining OpenAI to research and develop new ways for humans to interact with AI. TechCrunch Founder Summit 2026 will gather founders, investors, and decision-makers to discuss growth, execution, and real-world scaling. AI is also being used in unique ways, such as in dominant-submissive relationships.

## Market & Business Implications
* Burger King is using an AI-powered chatbot called "Patty" to evaluate employee interactions with customers and assist with meal preparation, as stated by Thibault Roux, Burger King's chief digital officer (Article 3).
* Salesforce reported $10.7 billion in revenue in the fourth quarter, with a 13% year-over-year increase, and offered strong guidance for the year ahead (Article 4).
* Riley Walz is joining OpenAI to research and develop new ways for humans to interact with AI, as part of the OAI Labs team led by research leader Joanne Jang (Article 5).
* TechCrunch Founder Summit 2026 will feature an exhibit hall where founders and operators can source tools and partners, with benefits including direct access to buyers and credibility that compounds (Article 1).
* Some individuals are using AI as a tool to enhance their dominant-submissive relationships, with AI-generated punishments and nonjudgmental spaces to ask questions (Article 2).

## Beginner-Friendly Summary
Burger King is using a computer program to help its employees be friendlier to customers. A big company called Salesforce made a lot of money, but some people are worried that artificial intelligence might change how they do business. A man named Riley Walz is joining a company that works with artificial intelligence to find new ways for people to use it. There's also a big meeting for business leaders to talk about how to grow and succeed. Some people are even using artificial intelligence in their personal relationships.

articles.title: Exhibit in Boston‚Äôs startup ecosystem at TechCrunch Founder Summit 2026
articles.text:

An exhibit table turns that energy into measurable growth. You don‚Äôt need more awareness. You need customers, capital, and strategic partners.

Secure your exhibit table and put your startup at the center of the startup universe.

Image Credits:Halo Creative

Why exhibiting drives real growth

Direct access to buyers: The Expo Hall is where founders and operators actively source tools and partners. Capture leads instantly through the event app and start building your pipeline on the spot.

Where handshakes replace cold pitches: Move from cold outreach to face-to-face conversations. With access to roundtables, breakouts, and curated networking, your team can turn visibility into velocity.

Credibility that compounds: Your startup is featured across the Founder Summit website, app, sponsor directory, announcements, and closing ceremony ‚Äî reinforcing trust with customers and investors alike.

Multi-channel ROI: Lead gen tools, sponsor listings, and team-wide passes mean you‚Äôre not just exhibiting. You‚Äôre executing across sales, marketing, and fundraising at the same time.

articles.title: Who‚Äôs Your Daddy? A Chatbot
articles.text:
The first time Alesandra Madison‚Äôs husband incorporated AI into their relationship was in late 2024.

She‚Äôd forgotten to do her ‚Äúnightly kneeling ritual,‚Äù and he asked ChatGPT how to properly discipline her. The large language model suggested ‚Äúa two-in-one punishment,‚Äù she says‚Äîwrite 100 lines of ‚ÄúI will remember to kneel for my Dom every night‚Äù while kneeling the entire time.

Though the couple started exploring kink in their marriage 15 years ago‚Äîthey are in a dominant-submissive relationship‚Äîthe AI-generated punishment was new territory for them.

Since then, Madison, who is 44 and lives in Los Angeles, says she has come to think of AI as ‚Äúa powerful enhancement tool‚Äù for kink. ‚ÄúA lot of the times in dom-sub dynamics, when the submissive misbehaves‚Äîif it‚Äôs consented to‚Äîyou will have a punishment. You want something specific to fit the crime, basically. It‚Äôs like a fresh set of eyes on your relationship.‚Äù

AI represents a unique evolution in how power is distributed for people into bondage and discipline, dominance and submission, and sadism and masochism‚ÄîBDSM. The lifestyle structure, as everyone WIRED spoke to for this story noted, is grounded in the core tenets of consent, safety, communication, and trust. But for those dealing with trust issues, or who simply want a nonjudgmental space to ask questions about BDSM, AI is becoming an increasingly appealing option.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve gotten value out of AI helping me understand myself better as a submissive. I sometimes ask it questions or describe something that feels confusing to me and ask it to help me understand,‚Äù one user posted in the r/SubSanctuary subreddit, where discussions involve topics like impact play, the feeling of ‚Äúbeing owned,‚Äù and how to move on when the relationship has reached its end. Madison says there are different reasons why AI doms appeal to certain subs. They are always available, easily customizable‚Äî‚ÄúYou can make them playful or sadistic,‚Äù she noted in a video‚Äîand there is low risk to exploring

articles.title: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff: This isn‚Äôt our first SaaSpocalypse
articles.text:
Salesforce pulled out all the stops to convince investors that the AI revolution won‚Äôt be its death when it announced fourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday.

Salesforce reported a solid quarter of $10.7 billion in revenue, up 13% year-over-year. For the year, it reported $41.5 billion in revenue, up 10% over the previous year, with both results boosted by its $8 billion acquisition of data management company Informatica last May.

Net income landed at $7.46 billion, and the company offered strong guidance for the year ahead, projecting revenue of $45.8 billion to $46.2 billion ‚Äî a 10% to 11% increase. It also said its ‚Äúremaining performance obligation,‚Äù or RPO, is over $72 billion. That‚Äôs a figure that shows revenue under contact that has not yet been delivered or recognized as earned revenue.

The numbers, though, could only do so much. Software-as-a-service stocks, with Salesforce as their poster child, have been getting hammered lately. Investors fear the rise of AI agents will undermine these companies, making their per-employee-seat business models obsolete. The situation has been dubbed the ‚ÄúSaaSpocalypse.‚Äù

The concept hung so heavily in the air during the earnings call that CEO Marc Benioff mentioned the term at least six times.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve heard about the SaaSpocalypse? And it isn‚Äôt our first. We‚Äôve had a few of them,‚Äù he said, later adding, ‚ÄúIf there is a SaaSpocalypse, it may be eaten by the Sasquatch because there are a lot of companies using a lot of SaaS because it just got better with agents.‚Äù

In an attempt to convince the world of its continued health, Salesforce threw everything and the kitchen sink into this earnings report. The company increased its dividend by nearly 6% to $0.44 per share. It launched a new $50 billion share buyback program. That‚Äôs always a favorite with shareholders because it both creates a sturdy buyer of shares and reduces the number of shares in circulation (which can boost the stock price).

Techcrunch event Save up to $300 or

articles.title: Riley Walz, the Jester of Silicon Valley, Is Joining OpenAI
articles.text:
Riley Walz, a software engineer famous for his online stunts, is joining OpenAI to research and develop new ways for humans to interact with AI, WIRED has learned. An OpenAI spokesperson confirmed the hire.

Walz built a reputation as Silicon Valley‚Äôs jester and has created a series of viral web projects that double as social commentary. His most recent initiative, Jmail, lets users search Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs emails as if they‚Äôre accessing his personal Gmail inbox. Another project, Find My Parking Cops, used publicly available data to reverse engineer San Francisco's parking ticket system to show people exactly where each parking enforcement officer last wrote a ticket.

Now, Walz‚Äôs skills creating novel web experiences will be put to use in OAI Labs, a relatively new team led by research leader Joanne Jang. The team is secretive about what it‚Äôs been working on but has been tasked with ‚Äúinventing and prototyping new interfaces for how people collaborate with AI,‚Äù according to Jang.

OpenAI has spent the past several years racing with Google and Anthropic to create new, compelling ways for people to use its AI models. While ChatGPT has been a hit with consumers, now reaching more than 800 million people every week, the company is eyeing new interfaces to improve these experiences. The move comes as millions of developers have started using coding agents such as Claude Code as their main interface to access AI models. With hires like Walz, OpenAI hopes to get ahead of the next big AI product.

Walz‚Äôs online stunts have landed him in hot water from time to time. The Find My Parking Cops website lasted just four hours before San Francisco city officials shut down the live data feed Walz‚Äôs tool relied on. A San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency representative said at the time that it shut down the tool to ensure ‚Äúemployees are able to do their jobs safely and without disruption.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not always city officials giving him a hard time, though. After the CEO of Unite

Finance.summary:
## Executive Summary
Nvidia's stock saw marginal gains despite better-than-expected earnings, as investor concerns around AI infrastructure spending dampened enthusiasm. The ultra-wealthy in America's richest ZIP code, Fisher Island, have a unique spending profile, with housing costs accounting for only 10% to 20% of their income. Meanwhile, West Palm Beach is becoming a hub for high-net-worth individuals, with luxury real estate developments catering to their needs. The stock market was mixed, with Dow Jones Industrial Average futures moving up 0.3%, while Nvidia shares pared gains to less than 1%. President Donald Trump claimed that beef, egg, and chicken prices are falling, but data shows that beef prices have increased during his second term.

## Market & Business Implications
* Nvidia's revenue for its fiscal fourth-quarter hit $68.13 billion, ahead of analyst estimates of $66.21 billion, according to Article 2.
* The median home in Fisher Island costs $9.5 million, and even with a $1 million down payment, monthly payments would be in the $65,000 range, including property taxes and insurance, as stated in Article 1.
* The Mandarin Oriental Residences in West Palm Beach will feature 87 residences with luxury amenities, catering to the growing "Billionaire Corridor" in the area, as reported in Article 3.
* Nvidia's guidance came in ahead of expectations, but concerns around AI capex spending and its sustainability weighed on investor minds, as mentioned in Article 2.
* Beef prices have increased 22% over the past year, from $5.55 per pound in January 2025 to $6.75 per pound in January 2026, according to data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, as stated in Article 5.

## Beginner-Friendly Summary
Some big companies are making a lot of money, but people who invest in them are not getting too excited. Really rich people in a place called Fisher Island spend their money differently than most people. They don't spend a lot on houses, even though their houses are very expensive. A new luxury building is being built in West Palm Beach for rich people. The president said that food prices are going down, but some foods like beef are actually getting more expensive. The stock market is a little bit up, but not by much.

articles.title: What‚Äôs a Typical Upper Class Spending Profile in America‚Äôs Richest ZIP Code?
articles.text:
The difference between the middle class and the upper middle class is incremental.

An upper-middle-class budget looks similar to a middle-class budget, simply with higher amounts spent. But the ultra-wealthy‚Äôs spending looks completely different from the upper middle class.

A 2025 study by PropertyShark listed the ten wealthiest ZIP codes in the country, topped by Fisher Island (33109) outside Miami. And there‚Äôs nothing ‚Äúaverage‚Äù about the average spending profile there.

Housing

The median home in Fisher Island costs $9.5 million. Even if they put down a $1 million down payment, they would still be looking at a monthly payment in the $65,000 range, including property taxes and insurance.

Financial planner Michael Harris of Emory Wealth notes that even at these numbers, the ultra-wealthy often spend just 10% to 20% of their income on housing.

‚ÄúIn top-tier ZIP codes, an ultra-wealthy family‚Äôs ‚Äòbudget‚Äô looks very different from the average household,‚Äù Harris added.

Find Out: The New 2026 Wealth Thresholds ‚Äî Where Your Income Places You in America‚Äôs Economic Ladder

Consider This: 6 Subtly Genius Moves All Wealthy People Make With Their Money

Taxes

At the highest end of the spectrum, Harris adds that the wealthy can lose 30% of their income to taxes. That includes not just regular income taxes but self-employment taxes, corporate taxes, capital gains taxes, dividend taxes and sales tax on expensive purchases.

Lifestyle

Lifestyle spending includes everything from cars to travel to household staff, and can vary wildly.

‚ÄúTheir lifestyles often include services and infrastructure that average households rarely consider,‚Äù explains Craig Kirsner, president at Kirsner Wealth Management. ‚ÄúThink private security, dedicated household staff, concierge services, exclusive club memberships, luxury transportation like yachts and jets, and premium wellness services.‚Äù

This spending could add up to another 20% to 50% of their budget.

Insurance and Risk Management

At this

articles.title: Nvidia's stock sees only marginal gains after better-than-expected results. Here's the latest
articles.text:
In this article NVDA Follow your favorite stocks CREATE FREE ACCOUNT

Nvidia stock is up almost 1% in pre-market trading on Thursday, as investor concerns around the AI infrastructure boom dampened enthusiasm about its better-than-expected earnings. Revenue for its fiscal fourth-quarter hit $68.13 billion, ahead of analyst estimates of $66.21 billion, according to LSEG. Total revenue climbed 73% from the figure Nvidia reported a year ago and guidance also came in ahead of expectations. "The debate has shifted away from near-term results and toward the sustainability of AI capex spending, amid concerns around its quantum, monetisation and potential cashflow degradation," Richard Clode, portfolio manager at Janus Henderson Investors, told CNBC by email.

Stock Chart Icon Stock chart icon Nvidia stock over the past year.

Investor AI concerns

Hyperscalers saw more than $1 trillion wiped from their market caps at the start of February, before paring those losses in recent weeks. Semiconductor AMD fell 17% after reporting guidance that topped expectations for many analysts earlier this month, though some had predicted a stronger outlook. "The market is currently fighting broad-based AI concerns," said Dan Hanbury, global strategic equity co-portfolio manager at Ninety One. "What is weighing heavy on investors' minds is how Nvidia can maintain its phenomenal growth rate now its core customers ‚Äî the hyperscalers ‚Äî are mostly depleting their cash flows, spending on AI-related capex."

Data centers fuel growth

articles.title: Wall Street South expansion: Mandarin Oriental anchors new ‚ÄòBillionaire Corridor‚Äô in West Palm Beach
articles.source: Latest Business News on Fox Business
articles.text:
EXCLUSIVE: The seasonal Florida resident is becoming a thing of the past. High-net-worth individuals are now moving entire corporate infrastructures to West Palm Beach, necessitating a new tier of ultra-prime real estate that functions as a year-round primary residence.

"People actually want to live and move to West Palm Beach, especially in this sort of area due to favorable business and maybe political conditions. And we love it," Great Gulf President of High-Rise Development Neil Vohrah told Fox News Digital.

"It's not just about the billionaires themselves, but more importantly, it's about the businesses that they bring, the companies they bring, the people they inspire and the opportunities that they create," Cervera Real Estate principal and managing partner Alicia Cervera Lamadrid also told Fox News Digital.

"There's a lot of wealth coming to this area," she added. "And, of course, it has to be accommodated."

‚ÄòTHIS PLACE WILL WIN‚Äô: BUSINESS LEADERS SAY WEST PALM BEACH IS BECOMING AMERICA'S NEXT BIG BOOMTOWN

On Thursday, the real estate juggernauts announced they‚Äôre launching the Mandarin Oriental Residences in West Palm Beach ‚Äî the brand‚Äôs first standalone residential property in South Florida. Located on North Flagler Drive in the growing "Billionaire Corridor," the building will eventually stand 31 stories and house 87 residences with all the familiar luxury a Mandarin Oriental property might offer.

The project unveiling comes on the heels of other major brands declaring their entry into the South Florida market, including Mr. C Residences in Boca Raton, Ritz-Carlton Residences in Fort Lauderdale Beach, Delano Residences Miami and Kempinski Residences in Miami Design District.

Catering to a "Wall Street South" demographic, the Mandarin prioritizes extreme privacy, resort-style amenities and includes space for in-home staff and executive offices. Residences range from 2,100 to 6,300 square feet, and feature two- to four-bedroom layouts.

The biggest d

articles.title: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq futures waver as Nvidia leaves investors wanting more
articles.text:
US stock futures nudged higher on Thursday as Nvidia's (NVDA) stellar earnings failed to wow investors, as Wall Street juggles growing worries over AI's potential for payoff and disruption.

Dow Jones Industrial Average futures (YM=F) moved up 0.3%, following solid wins for stocks more broadly on Wednesday. Contracts on the S&P 500 (ES=F) and the tech-exposed Nasdaq 100 (NQ=F) were little changed.

Nvidia shares jumped following its after-hours report Wednesday, but pared gains to less than 1% amid a lukewarm response from investors. The AI chipmaker posted big beats on quarterly revenue and profit, and its guidance also came in above expectations. But a lack of detail on drivers for the outlook ‚Äî which doesn't include potential revenue out of China ‚Äî left some on Wall Street asking questions about competitive threats and the staying power of AI buildout demand.

Fears of a AI bubble and the "AI scare trade" have buffeted stocks in recent weeks, with the technology's challenge to sectors such as legacy software coming to the fore. Salesforce (CRM) shares fell about 4% to continue an AI-driven sell-off after its revenue forecast fell short of estimates.

Elsewhere in earnings, Big Three automaker Stellantis (STLA) posted a massive $26.billion full-year loss after an EV-related charge, but a better showing in the second half suggested the Jeep maker's turnaround bid is taking hold. Quarterly reports from Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD), Dell Technologies (DELL), and CoreWeave (CRWV) are also on Thursday's docket.

On the macro front, a weekly update on jobless claims due later provides a health check on the labor market, as investors wait for the January wholesale inflation reading on Friday to help evaluate the odds of an interest-rate cut.

LIVE

11 updates

articles.title: Trump said beef, egg and chicken prices are falling. Here's what the data shows
articles.text:
In this article TSN

VITL Follow your favorite stocks CREATE FREE ACCOUNT

U.S. President Donald Trump delivers the State of the Union address on Feb. 24, 2026, in Washington, D.C. Kenny Holston-Pool/Getty Images

President Donald Trump said in his State of the Union speech Tuesday night that his administration's policies were "rapidly ending" high prices for certain foods, including proteins in the U.S. diet, like beef, chicken and eggs. However, prices for chicken and beef have increased since Trump took office in January 2025. Egg prices have indeed fallen significantly ‚Äî but, like beef prices, have been influenced more by supply-and-demand factors specific to those markets than federal policy, according to agricultural economists. The price moves also come as the Trump administration said it was "ending the war on protein" by announcing new U.S. nutrition guidelines that emphasize protein, full-fat dairy and vegetables. "President Trump is right: inflation has cooled, and prices of many everyday essentials have fallen or are on the right trajectory," White House spokesman Kush Desai said in an emailed statement. "The entire Administration remains laser-focused on delivering economic relief for the American people."

Beef prices have increased during Trump's second term

Trump said during his State of the Union address that beef prices are "starting to come down significantly." Federal data shows that beef prices have started to decline in some cases, but remain near multi-year or record highs. A pound of ground beef cost $6.75 per pound, on average, in January ‚Äî the highest level on record, according to data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Prices have increased 22% over the past year, from $5.55 per pound in January 2025, when Trump started his second term. That's the fastest annual inflation rate since June 2020, during Trump's first term in office.

Prices for other cuts of beef are also elevated, according to federal data. For example, the price of

World News.summary:
## Executive Summary
The US and Iran are set to hold nuclear talks in Geneva, which may be the last opportunity to avoid war. A Harvard professor, Larry Summers, has announced his resignation due to his ties with Jeffrey Epstein. In Uganda, two women have been arrested for allegedly kissing in public, which can lead to a life sentence. Additionally, the CEO of the World Economic Forum has quit after scrutiny over Epstein ties. 

## Market & Business Implications
* The US and Iran are scheduled to meet in Geneva to discuss Tehran's nuclear program, with Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi stating that there is a basis for an agreement, but ballistic missiles are off the table (Article 1).
* Harvard professor Larry Summers has announced his resignation from teaching due to his relationship with the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein (Article 1).
* The CEO of the World Economic Forum has quit after scrutiny over Epstein ties (Article 2).
* Spain will start checking arrivals from Gibraltar under a post-Brexit deal, with a system similar to that in operation at London's St Pancras station (Article 4).
* Former national security adviser John Bolton has discussed the risks of pursuing regime change in Iran (Article 5).

## Beginner-Friendly Summary
The US and Iran are talking about Iran's nuclear program to try to avoid war. A famous professor from Harvard is quitting his job because he knew a bad person named Jeffrey Epstein. In a country called Uganda, two women were arrested for kissing in public, which is against the law there. Also, a important business leader quit their job because of ties to Jeffrey Epstein.

articles.title: U.S. and Iran to hold nuclear talks. And, Harvard professor resigns over Epstein ties
articles.text:
U.S. and Iran to hold nuclear talks. And, Harvard professor resigns over Epstein ties

Good morning. You're reading the Up First newsletter. Subscribe here to get it delivered to your inbox, and listen to the Up First podcast for all the news you need to start your day.

Today's top stories

Officials from the U.S. and Iran are set to meet today in Geneva to discuss Tehran's nuclear program in what appears to be the last opportunity to avoid war. The development comes after President Trump claimed, without providing evidence, in his State of the Union address that Iran was developing missiles that could reach the U.S. The U.S. military buildup in the Middle East is currently at its highest level since the U.S. invaded Iraq in 2003.

toggle caption Costas Metaxakis/AFP via Getty Images

üéß The U.S.' threats against Iran and the possibility of Iranian retaliation have raised the risk of a wider war, putting the entire region on high alert, NPR's Jane Arraf tells Up First. Ahead of the two countries' meeting, Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said that there is a basis for an agreement with the U.S. on the nuclear issue, but made it clear that ballistic missiles are off the table. Arraf says no breakthroughs are expected today; however, scheduling more talks would signal progress. Meanwhile, several countries in the Middle East, such as Lebanon, are advising citizens to leave while they still can because of the risk of the conflict widening if Iran is attacked.

Sponsor Message

Prominent Harvard professor and economist Larry Summers announced his resignation from teaching later this year. His statement comes after a new revelation about Summers' relationship with the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Summers is one of Harvard's most well-known figures, serving as its president for five years starting in 2001. He was also Treasury secretary under President Bill Clinton. Harvard continues to investigate Summers and others for their ties to Epstein.



üéß

articles.title: CEO of World Economic Forum quits after Epstein ties scrutinised - Reuters
Two women arrested in Uganda for allegedly kissing in public could face life sentence
articles.text:
Two women have been arrested and detained in Uganda after allegedly kissing in public, an act of ‚Äúsame-sex activity‚Äù which can lead to a life sentence in the east African country..

Wendy Faith, a 22-year-old musician known as Torrero Bae, and Alesi Diana Denise, 21, were taken into custody after police raided their rented room in Uganda‚Äôs north-west Arua City last week.

‚ÄúInformation was received from the community that the suspects have been involved in queer and unusual acts believed to be sexual in nature, besides being allegedly seen kissing each other in broad daylight,‚Äù said Josephine Angucia, a police spokesperson for the West Nile region, which borders the Democratic Republic of Congo.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs further alleged ‚Ä¶ that many ladies normally converge to stay at the suspects‚Äô residence. It is upon that information that police acted by arresting the two female suspects under the allegation of practicing homosexuality,‚Äù she said.

The pair have been in custody since their arrest and it is not clear if or when they will formally be charged.

View image in fullscreen Uganda‚Äôs president, Yoweri Museveni. Photograph: AFP/Getty Images

Uganda‚Äôs autocratic president, Yoweri Museveni, signed the Anti-Homosexuality Act into law in May 2023, amid international and regional outrage. One of the world‚Äôs harshest anti-LGBTQ+ laws, it includes life imprisonment for same-sex relationships and the death penalty for ‚Äúaggravated homosexuality‚Äù.

Frank Mugisha, executive director, Sexual Minorities Uganda (Smug), said: ‚ÄúWe are closely following this case and are deeply alarmed by the arrest of the two young women. This incident is unjust and deeply troubling, and it is not an isolated case.

‚ÄúIn recent months, we have seen a sharp and disturbing increase in similar incidents across the country, where people are being reported, targeted, harassed and arrested based solely on allegations about their identity or relationships.‚Äù

Activists have condemned the growing wave of blackmail and

Business.summary:
## Executive Summary
The US Congress has approved a federal funding package that includes nearly $15.5 billion for congressionally directed spending, also known as earmarks, across 8,271 projects. Meanwhile, West Palm Beach is experiencing a surge in ultra-prime real estate development, with the launch of the Mandarin Oriental Residences, catering to high-net-worth individuals. Additionally, billionaire family offices have made significant investments in various sectors, including pro soccer, bitcoin, and semiconductors. The US government has also introduced "Trump accounts" for kids, which come with preferential tax treatment, but some states plan to tax these accounts as investment income.

## Market & Business Implications
* The 2026 federal funding package includes $15.5 billion for congressionally directed spending, which will be used to fund various projects across the US, including bridges, highways, and community centers (Article 1).
* The launch of the Mandarin Oriental Residences in West Palm Beach marks a significant development in the city's "Billionaire Corridor", catering to high-net-worth individuals and their businesses (Article 2).
* Billionaire family offices, such as Omega Advisors and Appaloosa, have made significant investments in various sectors, including pro soccer, bitcoin, and semiconductors, with some investments already paying off (Article 4).
* The introduction of "Trump accounts" for kids comes with preferential tax treatment, but some states, including California and Massachusetts, plan to tax these accounts as investment income (Article 5).

## Beginner-Friendly Summary
The US government has set aside a lot of money for special projects. Some of this money will be used to build things like roads and community centers. At the same time, a city in Florida called West Palm Beach is becoming a popular place for very rich people to live and do business. Some wealthy investors have also made big investments in things like soccer teams and technology companies. The government has also created a new type of savings account for kids, but some states might tax the money in these accounts.

articles.title: How $15.5 billion will be spent on Congress‚Äôs pet projects
articles.text:
Jazz history. Border helicopters. Oyster shell recycling. Tuna research. Film education. After one year off, the tradition of tucking millions of dollars for parochial projects into Congress‚Äôs annual funding legislation returned. The 2026 federal funding package passed earlier this month included nearly $15.5 billion across 8,271 projects in lawmakers‚Äô districts and states. An additional $273 million in earmarks are tucked into the Department of Homeland Security appropriations bill, which has not yet passed.

The funding ‚Äî formally known as ‚Äúcongressionally directed spending‚Äù and informally known as earmarks ‚Äî makes up just 1 percent of the $1.65 trillion in discretionary spending Congress has approved through Sept. 30, but it often receives outsize attention.

Critics argue the narrowly directed spending invites corruption, while proponents say it allows lawmakers to respond to local needs.

Either way, it provides a powerful incentive to keep lawmakers working toward bipartisan, full-year appropriations bills ‚Äî the process Congress nearly completed earlier this month after extending 2024‚Äôs funding levels for all of 2025.

‚ÄúMembers do care. It does provide motivation to get bills to the floor and across the finish line,‚Äù said Charles Kieffer, who spent decades in the Office of Management and Budget and working for the Senate Appropriations Committee.

The money will bolster bridges, highways, sewer systems and airport tarmacs; renovate community centers, homeless shelters, housing projects and libraries; fund new hospital equipment, public transit and workforce training programs and more.

The funded projects include $200,000 for an oral history initiative about jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan requested by Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-New York). Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) secured $129,000 for bluefin tuna research in the Atlantic Ocean. Sen. Cory Booker (D-New Jersey) got $80,000 for film education programs tied to a local film festival. Rep.

articles.title: Wall Street South expansion: Mandarin Oriental anchors new ‚ÄòBillionaire Corridor‚Äô in West Palm Beach
articles.source: Latest Business News on Fox Business
articles.text:
EXCLUSIVE: The seasonal Florida resident is becoming a thing of the past. High-net-worth individuals are now moving entire corporate infrastructures to West Palm Beach, necessitating a new tier of ultra-prime real estate that functions as a year-round primary residence.

"People actually want to live and move to West Palm Beach, especially in this sort of area due to favorable business and maybe political conditions. And we love it," Great Gulf President of High-Rise Development Neil Vohrah told Fox News Digital.

"It's not just about the billionaires themselves, but more importantly, it's about the businesses that they bring, the companies they bring, the people they inspire and the opportunities that they create," Cervera Real Estate principal and managing partner Alicia Cervera Lamadrid also told Fox News Digital.

"There's a lot of wealth coming to this area," she added. "And, of course, it has to be accommodated."

‚ÄòTHIS PLACE WILL WIN‚Äô: BUSINESS LEADERS SAY WEST PALM BEACH IS BECOMING AMERICA'S NEXT BIG BOOMTOWN

On Thursday, the real estate juggernauts announced they‚Äôre launching the Mandarin Oriental Residences in West Palm Beach ‚Äî the brand‚Äôs first standalone residential property in South Florida. Located on North Flagler Drive in the growing "Billionaire Corridor," the building will eventually stand 31 stories and house 87 residences with all the familiar luxury a Mandarin Oriental property might offer.

The project unveiling comes on the heels of other major brands declaring their entry into the South Florida market, including Mr. C Residences in Boca Raton, Ritz-Carlton Residences in Fort Lauderdale Beach, Delano Residences Miami and Kempinski Residences in Miami Design District.

Catering to a "Wall Street South" demographic, the Mandarin prioritizes extreme privacy, resort-style amenities and includes space for in-home staff and executive offices. Residences range from 2,100 to 6,300 square feet, and feature two- to four-bedroom layouts.

The biggest d

articles.title: Nearly a million 16-24 year-olds not working or in education
articles.text:
'It is a catastrophe' - the man battling to stem rising youth unemployment

Alan Milburn returns to his hometown of Newcastle as he undertakes a review into the growing numbers of young people out of work.

articles.title: Billionaire family offices invested in pro soccer, bitcoin and semiconductors before the new year
articles.text:
A version of this article first appeared in CNBC's Inside Wealth newsletter with Robert Frank, a weekly guide to the high-net-worth investor and consumer. Sign up to receive future editions, straight to your inbox.

Private investment firms of the ultra-wealthy capped off 2025 with equity bets ranging from airline stocks to bitcoin ETFs, according to fourth-quarter securities filings analyzed by CNBC.

Some of the investments made headlines. Leon Cooperman's family office, Omega Advisors, for example, attracted attention last week for disclosing that it had upped its stake in Manchester United last quarter. Omega Advisors' shares of the publicly traded English soccer club are now worth $46.5 million, per InsiderScore.

(Manchester fans fearing a takeover by the hedge-fund billionaire can rest easy. Another filing disclosing Cooperman's 5.2% stake in the club stated that his holding is a passive investment.)

While it generated less buzz, Omega Advisors' biggest move last quarter was buying more than $375 million worth of shares in mortgage lender Rocket Companies . The new position is now the firm's largest holding valued at nearly $407 million, per InsiderScore.

Some other moves by billionaire firms have already paid off. David Tepper's family office Appaloosa tripled its position in Micron to $428.1 million, making it the firm's top holding. Shares of Micron, which produces memory chips that power artificial intelligence data centers, have surged by roughly 50% since the start of 2026. During the same quarter, Stanley Druckenmiller's Duquesne Family Office initiated a new position in fuel-cell company Bloom Energy , which is up more than 100% year to date.

Bets on cryptocurrency have been less fruitful thus far this year. WIT LLC, an investment vehicle for the Walton family's namesake family office, made a $4 million allocation to iShares Bitcoin Trust ETF , which has sunk 21% year-to-date. The new position makes up less than 1% of WIT's portfolio. Duty-free mog

articles.title: The ‚ÄòTrump accounts‚Äô for kids come with a catch in some states
articles.text:
The White House has touted ‚ÄúTrump accounts‚Äù as a new way to grow a nest egg for children, with preferential tax treatment. But some states plan to tax those accounts as they would other investment income. The accounts, created through last year‚Äôs major tax law, are available starting in July to any U.S. citizens under 18 whose parents fill out a form opting in. Parents, employers, friends and philanthropies can invest in the accounts. And, as part of a pilot program, the U.S. Treasury will offer $1,000 to every participating child born between Jan. 1, 2025, and Dec. 31, 2028.

Although the accounts were designed to get less favorable tax treatment than 529 college savings plans, they impose fewer restrictions on how the money is spent. Recipients aren‚Äôt supposed to owe any taxes until the money is withdrawn, which can happen at any point after a child turns 18, in accordance with rules for traditional IRAs.

But despite a flashy rollout that included a Super Bowl ad this month, many U.S. states don‚Äôt recognize Trump accounts, which means the money isn‚Äôt shielded from taxes.

That‚Äôs not in issue in D.C. and the 20 states that automatically match federal tax law or in the nine states that don‚Äôt impose a personal income tax. The Washington Post asked the remaining 21 states whether earnings in Trump accounts would be taxed.

Seven said the annual earnings, under existing laws, would be considered taxable: California, Hawaii, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Wisconsin. Georgia, Maine, Vermont and Indiana said state legislation is under consideration to exempt the accounts from annual state taxes. Minnesota, Mississippi and North Carolina said the issue would be decided later.

Virginia and Idaho said the accounts would not be taxed annually.

Five states did not respond to The Post‚Äôs query.

Since the investment accounts will belong to minors, many participants will fall below the threshold that requires paying yearly taxes. But children who hav

Stock Market.summary:
## Executive Summary
IDEX's stock price has climbed to $206.19 per share, with a 24.2% return over the past six months, outpacing the S&P 500. Rolls-Royce has raised its outlook, expecting profits of over ¬£4 billion this year, and plans a share buyback of up to $12 billion. Stellantis, the Jeep maker, has reported its first annual loss in company history due to substantial write-downs amid a strategic shift. The stock market is seeing mixed reactions, with some stocks rising and others stalling.

## Market & Business Implications
* IDEX's core business is falling behind as demand plateaus, with no growth in organic revenue over the last two years, as stated in Article 1.
* Rolls-Royce expects underlying operating profit of between ¬£4 billion and ¬£4.2 billion in 2026, and plans to complete ¬£2.5 billion of share buybacks this year, as reported in Article 2.
* Stellantis has posted a full-year 2025 net loss of 22.3 billion euros, impacted by 25.4 billion euros in write-downs, as the firm sharply scales back its electric vehicle strategy, according to Article 4.

## Beginner-Friendly Summary
Some big companies are having different experiences. IDEX's stock is doing well, but the company itself is not growing as fast as it could be. Rolls-Royce is doing very well and plans to buy back some of its own shares. Stellantis, a car company, is having a tough time and lost a lot of money last year. The stock market is a little mixed, with some stocks going up and others not moving much.

articles.title: IDEX (IEX): Buy, Sell, or Hold Post Q4 Earnings?
articles.text:
IDEX‚Äôs 24.2% return over the past six months has outpaced the S&P 500 by 17.7%, and its stock price has climbed to $206.19 per share. This performance may have investors wondering how to approach the situation.

Is there a buying opportunity in IDEX, or does it present a risk to your portfolio? See what our analysts have to say in our full research report, it‚Äôs free.

Why Do We Think IDEX Will Underperform?

Despite the momentum, we're sitting this one out for now. Here are three reasons we avoid IEX and a stock we'd rather own.

1. Core Business Falling Behind as Demand Plateaus

We can better understand Gas and Liquid Handling companies by analyzing their organic revenue. This metric gives visibility into IDEX‚Äôs core business because it excludes one-time events such as mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures along with foreign currency fluctuations - non-fundamental factors that can manipulate the income statement.

Over the last two years, IDEX failed to grow its organic revenue. This performance was underwhelming and implies it may need to improve its products, pricing, or go-to-market strategy. It also suggests IDEX might have to lean into acquisitions to accelerate growth, which isn‚Äôt ideal because M&A can be expensive and risky (integrations often disrupt focus).

IDEX Organic Revenue Growth

2. EPS Took a Dip Over the Last Two Years

While long-term earnings trends give us the big picture, we also track EPS over a shorter period because it can provide insight into an emerging theme or development for the business.

Sadly for IDEX, its EPS declined by 1.7% annually over the last two years while its revenue grew by 2.8%. This tells us the company became less profitable on a per-share basis as it expanded.

IDEX Trailing 12-Month EPS (Non-GAAP)

3. New Investments Fail to Bear Fruit as ROIC Declines

We like to invest in businesses with high returns, but the trend in a company‚Äôs ROIC can also be an early indicator of future business quality.

We like to invest

articles.title: Rolls-Royce raises outlook, plans up to $12 billion share buyback as engine demand boosts growth
articles.text:
Rolls-Royce said Thursday it expects profits of over ¬£4 billion ($5.42 billion) this year as the aero engine and power systems maker promised another year of robust growth.

The aerospace giant is targeting underlying operating profit of between ¬£4 billion and ¬£4.2 billion in 2026, above the midpoint of ¬£3.65 billion as expected by analysts polled by FactSet. It expects free cash flow of between ¬£3.6 billion and ¬£3.8 billion this year, also above expectations.

It also announced that ¬£2.5 billion of share buybacks would be completed this year as part of a multi-year buyback program of between ¬£7 billion and ¬£9 billion ($12 billion) for 2026 to 2028, above what earlier media reports had suggested.

Shares rose as much as 7% in early trading on Thursday. The stock last traded up 4.5% and was on track for a record high after already reaching new highs multiple times this year.

Based on the bullish outlook, the company now expects to deliver profits within the prior mid-term guidance range two years earlier than planned, CEO Tufan Erginbilgic said.

"Our transformation continues with pace and intensity," he said in a statement.

The British company upgraded its 2028 targets to ¬£4.9 billion to ¬£5.2 billion in underlying operating profit, an operating margin in the range of 18% to 20%, and free cash flow of ¬£5 billion to ¬£5.3 billion. Beyond the mid-term, Erginbilgic said he expected his company to benefit from AI, the energy transition, and increased defense spending.

Rolls-Royce shares have been on a tear over the past few years amid growth in all three of its businesses: civil aerospace, defense, and power systems. Over the past 12 months, the stock has more than doubled as the company has thrived amid a transformation plan launched by Erginbilgic, which has boosted investor confidence. The plan includes cutting costs and prioritizing its core businesses.

articles.title: Stock Futures Inch Higher After Nvidia‚Äôs Stellar Earnings as Tech Rebound Stalls
articles.text: Stock futures were up slightly Thursday even after Nvidia convincingly beat earnings and guidance expectations as the strong tech rebound looked set to take a pause. Dow futures ticked 0.2% higher, while those tied to the Nasdaq 100 were flat. Stocks rallied for a second day Wednesday as investors appeared to shake off the panic over artificial intelligence that rocked markets at the start of the week following a viral note from Citrini Research.

articles.title: Jeep maker Stellantis posts first annual loss in company history after EV writedowns
articles.text:
Antonio Filosa attends the presentation of the new Fiat 500 Hybrid at the Stellantis FIAT Mirafiori plant in Turin, Italy, on November 25, 2025.

Auto giant Stellantis on Thursday reported its first-ever annual loss after booking substantial write-downs amid a major strategic shift.

The multinational conglomerate, which owns household names including Jeep, Dodge, Fiat, Chrysler and Peugeot, posted a full-year 2025 net loss of 22.3 billion euros ($26.3 billion), compared to full-year profit of 5.5 billion euros a year ago.

The net loss was impacted by 25.4 billion euros in write-downs, Stellantis said, as the firm sharply scales back its electric vehicle strategy.

The results come as carmakers across the globe look to walk back their EV plans. Car giants including GM , Ford and Honda , for example, have all announced billions of dollars in charges to write-down EV investments in recent months. The trend underscores the shifting dynamics at play on the road to full electrification.

"Our 2025 full year results reflect the cost of over-estimating the pace of the energy transition and of the need to reset our business around our customers' freedom to choose from the full range of electric, hybrid and internal combustion technologies," Stellantis CEO Antonio Filosa said in a statement.

"In 2026 our focus will be on continuing to close the execution gaps of the past, adding further momentum to our return to profitable growth," he added.

Stellantis said it had suspended its dividend for 2026, as it had previously flagged, and issued up to 5 billion euros of hybrid bonds. It also reiterated its 2026 forecasts, including a mid-single-digit percentage increase in net revenues and a low-single-digit adjusted operating margin.

articles.title: Exchange-Traded Funds, Equity Futures Higher Pre-Bell Thursday as Investors Analyze Nvidia Results
articles.text:
The broad market exchange-traded fund SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) was up 0.1% and the actively trad

Crypto.summary:
## Executive Summary
MetaMask has launched a Mastercard-enabled spending card in the US, allowing users to spend their crypto securely and seamlessly. The card is available in 49 states, with Vermont being the only exception. Circle has reported strong Q4 earnings, with USDC circulation reaching $75.3B and revenue up 77%. Grvt has integrated Aave to let traders earn yield on collateral posted for margin. OKX has integrated Chainalysis Alterya for pre-withdrawal scam screening.

## Market & Business Implications
* MetaMask has launched a Mastercard-enabled spending card in the US, with the card being available in 49 states, as stated by a Consensys spokesperson in Article 1.
* Circle reported Q4 earnings with USDC circulation reaching $75.3B, up 72% year-over-year, as mentioned in Article 4.
* Grvt has integrated Aave to let traders earn yield on collateral posted for margin, with the feature applying to USDt (USDT) collateral, as stated in Article 3.
* OKX has integrated Chainalysis Alterya for pre-withdrawal scam screening, with Alterya analyzing scam infrastructure across websites, social media, and messaging channels, as mentioned in Article 5.
* The MetaMask Card is issued by Cross River Bank, a US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) insured bank, as stated in Article 1.

## Beginner-Friendly Summary
A new card has been launched that lets people use their crypto money to buy things. This card is available in almost all states in the US. A company called Circle had a very good last quarter, with a lot of people using their service. Another company, Grvt, is now working with Aave to help people make more money from their crypto. A crypto exchange called OKX is using a new tool to help stop scams.

articles.title: Mastercard, MetaMask launch US crypto card, debuting in New York
articles.text:
Self-custodial cryptocurrency wallet MetaMask is rolling out its Mastercard-enabled spending card in the United States, with first-time availability in New York.

MetaMask parent company Consensys on Thursday announced the general availability of the MetaMask Card across the US following initial pilots in 2025 and 2024.

With the US launch, MetaMask Card joins existing availability in Argentina, Brazil, Canada, European Economic Area countries, Mexico, Switzerland and the United Kingdom, with additional markets to follow, the company said in an announcement shared with Cointelegraph.

‚ÄúThis is the first time MetaMask Card is available across 49 states, and the first time users in New York can access it,‚Äù a spokesperson for Consensys said, adding that Vermont is the only exception.

‚ÄúMetaMask shares our vision of empowering people to spend their crypto securely and seamlessly ‚Äî anywhere Mastercard is accepted in the world,‚Äù said Sherri Haymond, global head of digital commercialization at Mastercard.

Full self-custody until the point of payment

Built in partnership with regulated issuer Monavate (formerly Baanx) and Mastercard‚Äôs global payments network, the MetaMask Card is issued by Cross River Bank, a US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) insured bank.

The company said the card works at 150 million Mastercard merchants worldwide, online or in-store, and is compatible with Apple Pay and Google Pay.

MetaMask opened a waiting list for the MetaMask Card in March 2025. Source: MetaMask

A core feature of the card is self-custody, which lets users store crypto independently and retain full control until the point of purchase.

‚ÄúUnlike most traditional crypto cards, which are custodial and require users to pre-load funds onto an exchange account, MetaMask Card is fully self-custodial,‚Äù the company said in the announcement.

‚ÄúUsers retain control of their digital assets in their MetaMask wallet until the moment they pay.‚Äù

As part of the launch, MetaMask will

articles.title: MetaMask Crypto Debit Mastercard Launches Across United States
articles.text: Add Decrypt as your preferred source to see more of our stories on Google. In brief The MetaMask Card is now accessible to all users across the United States, following a piloted rollout across select geographies. The card allows users to spend wherever Mastercard is accepted using their self-custodied crypto funds. In addition to its free card, the brand is unveiling a premium subscription card with additional benefits and increased cash back rewards. The MetaMask debit card is now available for users across the United States. Created in collaboration between Ethereum software firm Consensys‚Äîone of 22 investors in an editorially independent Decrypt‚Äîand Mastercard, the card was initially rolled out in 2024 for a limited pilot in the United Kingdom and European Union, allowing users to make everyday purchases using their crypto balances. Now all U.S. users will be able to do the same. ‚ÄúWith MetaMask Card, your assets stay in your wallet‚Äîunder your control‚Äîuntil the exact moment you make a purchase,‚Äù MetaMask Staff Product Manager Ale Machado told Decrypt. ‚ÄúThere's no handing your funds to someone else and hoping they're there when you need them.‚Äù Ôªø ‚ÄúFor crypto-native users who already hold stablecoins,‚Äù he added, ‚Äúthis unlocks real everyday utility without sacrificing the principles that brought them to crypto in the first place.‚Äù Alongside bringing access to American users, the firm also unveiled a premium MetaMask card with added benefits. For $199 a year, users can obtain the ‚Äúelevated physical experience‚Äù of the MetaMask Metal Card, which offers up to 3% cashback on the first $10,000 spent per year. By comparison, standard cardholders may receive up to 1% cashback on purchases. ‚ÄúThe Metal Card is for users who want to go further,‚Äù said Machado. On top of the cash back, premium holders will also get ‚Äúno foreign transaction fees, higher spendin

articles.title: Grvt integrates Aave so traders can earn yield on perp collateral
articles.text:
Decentralized perpetual futures exchange (perp DEX) Grvt said it has integrated the Aave lending protocol to let traders earn yield on collateral posted for margin while keeping their derivatives positions open.

The company said Thursday that the feature is designed to reduce the opportunity cost of margin collateral that typically sits idle on trading venues. Perpetual futures are crypto derivatives that track an asset‚Äôs price and do not expire.

‚ÄúOn most platforms, your capital can only do one thing at a time,‚Äù Hong Yea, CEO of Grvt, told Cointelegraph. ‚ÄúYour stablecoins are either earning yield or available to trade, but not both.‚Äù He said the integration aims to let users deposit once and use the same capital as active margin while earning lending returns.

The announcement comes as crypto derivatives continue to be a major source of fee generation across decentralized finance. Data from analytics platform DefiLlama shows DeFi protocols have generated more than $1 billion in quarterly revenue in recent periods, with derivatives exchanges contributing a large portion.

Top 20 revenue protocols excluding stablecoin issuers. Source: DefiLlama

On X, DefiLlama‚Äôs head of revenue and growth, Patrick Scott, wrote that onchain businesses are finding their product-market fit.

Related: DeFi perps volume explodes past $1T in record month so far

Capital efficiency becomes a competitive focus

Perpetual futures traders typically post stablecoins as collateral and leave them parked to meet margin requirements. At launch, Grvt said the feature applies to USDt (USDT) collateral, which is tokenized 1:1 against deposits deployed into Aave‚Äôs lending pools.

‚ÄúWhen liquidation happens, we take over their positions and liquidate just like it would happen with USDT,‚Äù Yea told Cointelegraph. He said that funds can be withdrawn from Aave within about 10 minutes to service redemptions.

Related: Aave surpasses $1T in lending volume amid institutional expansion

Returns are sourced fro

Crypto stocks saw the love as well, with Coinbase closing up 13% and Strategy up 9%.

Jeremy Allaire on the earnings call: ‚ÄúTens or hundreds of billions of AI agents will interact and perform economic functions over the internet.‚Äù

Clear Street analysts to Decrypt: ‚ÄúThe print reinforces continued USDC adoption despite a softer crypto backdrop.‚Äù

üß† Why It Matters

Circle‚Äôs Q4 performance was massive and their poised to keep going.

articles.title: OKX integrates Chainalysis Alterya for pre-withdrawal scam screening
articles.text:
Crypto exchange OKX has expanded its relationship with blockchain analytics company Chainalysis by integrating Alterya, a fraud-detection platform designed to identify scam-related payment destinations before funds are sent.

The partnership reflects a broader shift among exchanges from post-transaction blockchain monitoring toward earlier intervention, particularly in cases where users are persuaded to transfer funds to scam-controlled accounts, OKX told Cointelegraph.

Alterya analyzes scam infrastructure across websites, social media and messaging channels, and links those signals to financial identifiers such as crypto wallets and bank accounts. Integrated into withdrawal flows, the system allows exchanges to flag or block transfers to addresses believed to be associated with active scams.

Traditional anti-money laundering (AML) tools typically focus on the sender through Know Your Customer (KYC) checks and transaction monitoring. Alterya instead concentrates on the recipient side, identifying wallets and accounts tied to scam networks or money mule operations.

Chainalysis acquired Alterya early last year in a deal reportedly valued at $150 million, marking its expansion beyond blockchain tracing into real-time fraud prevention for payments.

Prior to the acquisition, Alterya worked with exchanges including Coinbase and Binance. The company says its systems monitor more than $23 billion in monthly transaction volume and has prevented $300 million in losses over the past 12 months.

Related: US seizes $61M in USDT linked to ‚Äòpig butchering‚Äô crypto fraud scheme

The blockchain industry‚Äôs growing focus on prevention tools

Blockchain risk monitoring and fraud intelligence platforms have expanded in recent years as exchanges and payment providers respond to rising scam-related losses.

Blockchain analytics companies such as TRM Labs and Elliptic, long known for transaction tracing and sanctions screening, now offer wallet risk scoring and real-time transaction mon
